column2: petrography and chemistry of Zr-rich accessory minerals (zirconolite
column3: tranquillityite and baddeleyite) in mare basalt 10047|Rasmussen
column8: Janet R.|Geochimica et Cosmochimica Acta|72|23|5799|In situ U-Pb isotopic measurements were carried out by ion microprobe on the Zr-rich accessory minerals zirconolite [CaZrTi <SUB>2</SUB>O <SUB>7</SUB>]
column10: high-Ti mare basalt 10047 collected during the Apollo 11 mission. The analysed minerals are concentrated in pockets of late-stage mesostasis that comprises an intergrowth of silica
column17: cristobalite and troilite. Most Zr-rich minerals are unaltered
column19: some tranquillityite is replaced by a complex intergrowth of zirconolite
column22: suggesting that the mineral became unstable during crystallization. Several baddeleyite crystals have also undergone alteration to secondary zircon. Zirconolite was analysed in thin section 10047
column25: using a ̃6 μm primary ion beam. Both zirconolite and tranquillityite have significant U and low initial Pb contents
column26: and are highly suitable for Pb/Pb dating. Fifteen analyses of zirconolite give a <SUP>207</SUP>Pb/ <SUP>206</SUP>Pb age of 3708 ± 7 Ma ( <SUP>207</SUP>Pb/ <SUP>206</SUP>Pb: <SUP>204</SUP>Pb/ <SUP>206</SUP>Pb isochron; 95% confidence
column27: including renormalisation of ratios) and twenty-five analyses of tranquillityite give 3710 ± 6 Ma. The <SUP>207</SUP>Pb/ <SUP>206</SUP>Pb dates are consistent with each other and refine results from an earlier study. Baddeleyite data were less precise
column28: mainly due to lower secondary ionisation efficiency. Our results show that zirconolite and tranquillityite can provide precise isotopic dates and
column29: given their presence in other samples
column30: they represent important U-Pb chronometers for refining lunar geology.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.gca.2008.09.010

column1: 1984LPSC...15..171E|1984|Cosmic ray exposure histories and U-235-Xe-136 dating of Apollo 11
column12: H.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|89||C171|The history of exposure to cosmic rays was studied for nine basaltic rocks based on the cosmic-ray-produced noble gas isotopes. The results for the five basalts 10003
column16: and 77135 are consistent with a single-stage exposure. Four basalts
column21: experienced a multistage exposure. Using the U-235-Xe-136 dating method
column22: the time of their early exposure to cosmic rays on the lunar surface was dated to have begun three to four aeons ago
column23: immediately after rock formation as defined by their crystallization ages. The durations and shielding depths for the proposed two-stage exposure models of the four basalts were calculated. From the shielding at the early stage
column24: a lower limit of 50 cm is estimated for the thickness of the lava flows from which the investigated basalts originate.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1029/JB089iS01p0C171

column4: D. P.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||49|A reexamination of the bulk major and trace element geochemistry of Apollo 11 low-K mare basalts is presented. New analyses are given for seven previously unanalyzed samples (10003
column10: and 10062) and for two low-K basalts (10029 and 10092) and one high-K basalt (10071) for which comprehensive compositional data were previously lacking. The data show that three distinct magma types have been sampled
column11: as proposed by Beaty and Albee (1978)
column12: and that these magma types are unrelated by near-surface crystal fractionation. Each magma type is characterized by distinctive magmaphile element ratios
column13: which enable previously unclassified samples (10050 and 10062) to be assigned to an appropriate magma type.|

column14: A.|Lunar and Planetary Science Conference Proceedings|1||1|Previously unpublished (Ar-39)-(Ar-40) ages and exposure ages are presented for Apollo 11 whole rocks and mineral separates. column1: 1974E&PSL..21..164L|1974|Lunar monazite: A late-stage (mesostasis) phase in mare basalt|Lovering
column8: R.|Earth and Planetary Science Letters|21|2|164|Thorium-poor monazite occurs as an inclusion in a ferrohedenbergite grain within a mesostasis area of the relatively coarse-grained Apollo 11 basalt 10047
column9: 68. Only a single grain of monazite (̃ 4 × 15 μm) has been observed but it is possible that monazite may exist as a more significant phase at smaller grain sizes. Electron probe analyses indicate chondrite-normalized REE fractionation patterns for both lunar and terrestrial monazites in which the light REE's (La to Sm) are highly enriched relative to the heavy REE's (Gd to Lu). Lunar monazite shows a distinct Eu anomaly which is absent from the terrestrial sample. Crystallization of monazite from late-stage liquids forming during crystallization of lunar igneous rocks could lead to these liquids becoming increasingly depleted in the light REE's relative to the heavy REE's.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0012-821X(74)90050-8

column1: 1972Moon....4...93B|1972|Polarized Absorption Spectra of Single Crystals of Lunar Pyroxenes and Olivines|Burns
column6: Rateb M.|Moon|4|1-2|93|Measurements have been made of the polarized absorption spectra (360-2200 nm.) of compositionally zoned pyroxene minerals in rocks 10045
column7: 10047 and 10058 and olivines in rocks 10020 and 10022. Specimens in the form of petrographic thin sections were mounted on polarizing microscopes equipped with three-axis universal stage attachments and inserted into a Cary 17 spectrophotometer. The Apollo 11 pyroxenes with relatively high Ti/Fe ratios were chosen initially to investigate the presence of crystal field spectra of Fe<SUP>2+</SUP> and Ti<SUP>3+</SUP> ions in the minerals. Broad intense bands at about 1000 and 2100 nm. arise from spin-allowed
column8: polarization-dependent transitions in Fe<SUP>2+</SUP> ions in pyroxenes. Several weak sharp peaks occur in the visible region. Peaks at 402
column11: 550 and 585 nm. represent spin-forbidden transitions in Fe<SUP>2+</SUP> ions
column12: while broader bands at 460 470 nm. and 650 660 nm. are attributed to Ti<SUP>3+</SUP> ions. Charge transfer bands
column13: which in terrestrial pyroxenes often extend into the visible region
column14: are displaced to shorter wavelengths in lunar pyroxenes. This feature correlates with the absence of Fe<SUP>3+</SUP> ions in these minerals. The magnitudes of the intensity ratios: band 465 nm. (Ti<SUP>3+</SUP>) to band 1000 nm. (Fe<SUP>2+</SUP>) are similar to Ti/Fe ratios from lunar pyroxene bulk chemical analyses
column15: suggesting that an appreciable amount of titanium occurs as Ti<SUP>3+</SUP> ions in the lunar pyroxenes. The 505 nm. spin-forbidden peak in Fe<SUP>2+</SUP>
column16: together with absorption at 465 nm. by Ti<SUP>3+</SUP>
column17: contribute to the pink or pale reddish-brown colors of lunar pyroxenes in transmitted lights. The absorption spectral measurements not only provide information on the redox behavior and crystal chemistry of lunar pyroxenes
column18: but also form a basis for interpreting spectral reflectivity properties of lunar rocks and the Moon's surface.|http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/BF00562917
